natural problem: An amoeba is placed in a puddle one day, and on that same day it splits into two amoebas.  The next day, each new amoeba splits into two new amoebas, and so on, so that each day every living amoeba splits into two new amoebas. After one week, how many amoebas are in the puddle? (Assume the puddle has no amoebas before the first one is placed in the puddle.)
natural solution: At the end of the first day, there are 2 amoebas. At the end of the second, there are $2\cdot 2 = 2^2$ amoebas. At the end of the third day, there are $2\cdot 2^2 = 2^3$ amoebas, and so on.
So, after the seventh day, there are $2^7= \boxed{128}$ amoebas.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes amoeba :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "amoeba 1 = 2"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n > 1 \<longrightarrow> amoeba n = 2 * amoeba (n-1)"
shows  "amoeba 7 = 128"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An amoeba is placed in a puddle one day, and on that same day it splits into two amoebas.  The next day, each new amoeba splits into two new amoebas, and so on, so that each day every living amoeba splits into two new amoebas. After one week, how many amoebas are in the puddle? (Assume the puddle has no amoebas before the first one is placed in the puddle.) The final Answer is 128
 ### Proof
 At the end of the first day, there are 2 amoebas. At the end of the second, there are $2\cdot 2 = 2^2$ amoebas. At the end of the third day, there are $2\cdot 2^2 = 2^3$ amoebas, and so on.
 So, after the seventh day, there are $2^7= \boxed{128}$ amoebas.
 *)

theorem
fixes amoeba :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "amoeba 1 = 2"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n > 1 \<longrightarrow> amoeba n = 2 * amoeba (n-1)"
shows  "amoeba 7 = 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: An amoeba doubles in number every day. If there is 1 amoeba on the first day, how many amoebas will there be after 7 days? The answer is 128.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes amoebas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "amoebas 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>day. day \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> amoebas day = 2 * amoebas (day - 1)"
shows  "amoebas 7 = 128"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An amoeba is placed in a puddle one day, and on that same day it splits into two amoebas.  The next day, each new amoeba splits into two new amoebas, and so on, so that each day every living amoeba splits into two new amoebas. After one week, how many amoebas are in the puddle? (Assume the puddle has no amoebas before the first one is placed in the puddle.) The final Answer is 128
 ### Proof
 At the end of the first day, there are 2 amoebas. At the end of the second, there are $2\cdot 2 = 2^2$ amoebas. At the end of the third day, there are $2\cdot 2^2 = 2^3$ amoebas, and so on.
 So, after the seventh day, there are $2^7= \boxed{128}$ amoebas.
 *)

theorem
fixes amoebas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "amoebas 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>day. day \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> amoebas day = 2 * amoebas (day - 1)"
shows  "amoebas 7 = 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Starting with one amoeba, suppose the number of amoebas doubles every day. How many amoebas will there be after 7 days? The final answer is 128.

shows  "amoebas 7 = 128"

fixes amoebas day :: nat

and h1 : "\<forall>day. amoebas (Suc day) = 2 * amoebas day"

a_5.formal problem:
theorem amoebas_after_one_week:
fixes amoebas :: nat and day :: nat
assumes h0 : "amoebas 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>day. amoebas (day + 1) = 2 * amoebas day"
shows  "amoebas 7 = 128"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 An amoeba is placed in a puddle one day, and on that same day it splits into two amoebas.  The next day, each new amoeba splits into two new amoebas, and so on, so that each day every living amoeba splits into two new amoebas. After one week, how many amoebas are in the puddle? (Assume the puddle has no amoebas before the first one is placed in the puddle.) The final Answer is 128
 ### Proof
 At the end of the first day, there are 2 amoebas. At the end of the second, there are $2\cdot 2 = 2^2$ amoebas. At the end of the third day, there are $2\cdot 2^2 = 2^3$ amoebas, and so on.
 So, after the seventh day, there are $2^7= \boxed{128}$ amoebas.
 *)

theorem amoebas_after_one_week:
fixes amoebas :: nat and day :: nat
assumes h0 : "amoebas 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>day. amoebas (day + 1) = 2 * amoebas day"
shows  "amoebas 7 = 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: An amoeba population doubles every day. If there is initially 1 amoeba, how many amoebas will there be after one week (7 days)? The final answer is 128.

fixes amoebas :: nat
assumes h0 : "amoebas = 1"
and h1 : "amoebas = amoebas * 2 ^ n"
shows  "amoebas * 2 ^ 7 = 128"

(* ### Problem

theorem
fixes n :: nat and amoebas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "amoebas 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. amoebas (Suc n) = 2 * amoebas n"
shows  "amoebas 7 = 128"

 *)

fixes n :: nat and amoebas :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "amoebas 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. amoebas (Suc n) = 2 * amoebas n"
shows  "amoebas 7 = 128"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: An amoeba population doubles every day. If there is 1 amoeba on day 0, how many amoebas will there be after 7 days? The final answer is 128.

shows  "amoebas 7 = 128"
 proof-
